'''Rita Corinne Hosking''' is an American composer and musician based in [[Davis, California]].  She plays [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] styles of music with both standards and original songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>  Since the release of ''Are You Ready?'', she has been performing around the country at concerts, festivals, and other venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |title=Rita Hosking homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304104821/http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |archive-date=2012-03-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.napavalleyregister.com/articles/2008/05/28/arts/doc483ccce3003cb396119897.txt |title=Article about benefit performance in Napa by Rita Hosking & Cousin Jack |publisher=Napavalleyregister.com |date=2008-05-28 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

"Hosking's music isn't like the polished, over-produced music found in pop culture. Hers is a minimalist sound that reflects a simpler time and place: a little country town, rather than a big city."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:DVEB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1106562C5F3184F8&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FCEDEB95BD4D563 |title=Channeling simpler times - Folksinger records her own life and upbringing in old-style ballads by Landon Christensen |publisher=Docs.newsbank.com |date=2006-03-14 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

Leading up to her 2010 performance tour of Great Britain, she received increasing attention on the "East Side" of the pond.   Reviewer Paul Kerr of Americana-UK remarked that she is ". . . a very talented artist with the ability to step up to that pantheon of great female country folk singers and writers."  <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |title=Review by Paul Kerr in Americana-UK, ''Superb country folk from a brilliant singer/songwriter'' 2010 |publisher=Americana-uk.com |date=2010-01-11 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929220958/http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |archive-date=2011-09-29 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  In the summer of 2010, Hosking played to packed venues in England, Wales, and Cornwall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mythankyoupage.com/2010/07/28/rita-hosking-at-no8-cafe-in-launceston/ |title=Review of Hosking and Feder's performance on July 22, 2010, at No8 Cafe in Launceston, Cornwall |publisher=Mythankyoupage.com |date= 28 July 2010|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Influences and inspirations==
Hosking grew up in a rural area in [[Shasta County, California]].  Her father worked the night shift at a sawmill as part of the area's logging industry. Her great-grandfather, from [[Cornwall]], southwest of England, was an underground coal miner in the region. Her grandmother's family had headed there in a covered wagon on the Oregon Trail, from Virginia.

Hosking says old-time music was strong in her mountain area, as well as country. She grew up hearing neighbors play their simple instruments by ear, as a group called the Mountaineers. And the school cook took several girls from the school, taught them songs and they performed as the Farmerettes; with the Farmerettes, Hosking played washboard and sang her first solo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |title=Article by Patrick S. Pemberton, The Tribune, San Luis Obispo, California. Friday, June 18, 2010. |publisher=Californiachronicle.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312055628/http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |archive-date=March 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

''"I'm no expert on the Appalachians at all, but I figure there are similarities -- the economy and some traditions, logging and mining. So, as a songwriter, you focus on that. You take the human struggle to survive, particularly in a beautiful place they love, and you've pinned down a lot of artistic inspiration."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginawnews/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-1/1217654410164730.xml&coll=9 |title=California singer understands folk roots |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-02 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Performances==

By invitation, she has appeared at the White Crow Conservatory of Music in Saginaw, Michigan,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginaw/index.ssf/2008/08/on_stage_rita_hosking_white.html |title=Rita Hosking brings mountain music, California style, to Saginaw's White Crow by Janet I. Martineau, The Saginaw News |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-01 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> the 17th Annual [https://archive.today/20110715002124/http://www.onemorebluegrassshow.com/Home_Page.html/ “Midsummer in the Northwoods” Bluegrass Festival] in Wisconsin, high in the Colorado Rockies at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090531084110/http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/index.html Telluride Bluegrass Festival], and many other locations.

On July 16, 2010, she performed at the [[Larmer Tree Festival]] in England, at the famed Victorian pleasure garden on the Wiltshire/Dorset border.  On July 22, she was the featured guest on the BBC radio show ''Bob Harris Country''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00t38hp/Bob_Harris_Country_Rita_Hosking_in_session/ |title=Bob Harris Country on BBC Radio |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-07-22 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> On November 3, 2010, she performed at [[The Freight and Salvage]] Coffeehouse in Berkeley, California.<ref>{{cite web|date=|title=Announcement of Freight & Salvage performance of November 3, 2010|url=http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928054652/http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|archive-date=September 28, 2011|accessdate=2011-11-04|publisher=Thefreight.org}}</ref>

Hosking has also performed at many popular festivals including the Strawberry Music Festival, Live Oak Music Festival, Kate Wolf Music Festival and [[Sisters Folk Festival]].

==Recognition and awards==
Rita was the ''2007 Emerging Artist Winner'' at the Bluegrassin' In The Foothills festival in [[Plymouth, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.landspromotions.com/plymouthhome.htm |title=Homepage of the annual music festival in Plymouth, California ''Bluegrassin' in the Foothills'' |publisher=Landspromotions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

On September 6, 2008, Rita was selected the winner of the nationally respected ''Dave Carter Memorial Songwriting Contest'' at the [[Sisters Folk Festival]] in [[Sisters, Oregon]].<ref>[http://www.sistersfolkfestival.org Sisters Folk Festival homepage]</ref>

On June 18, 2009, Rita performed as a finalist at the acclaimed Telluride Troubadour Competition, held in conjunction with the [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]].  The Competition judges songs based on composition, vocal delivery, and overall performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/contests.html |title=Telluride Bluegrass competitions |publisher=Bluegrass.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

"Come Sunrise" was nominated in November 2009 as one of the five finalists for Album of the Year in the category of "country music" by the 9th annual Independent Music Awards.<ref>[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/rita-hosking-9th-ima-country-album-nominee/ Artist Spotlight, nominee for Country Music ''album of the year'', 9th Annual Independent Music Awards.]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref>  Hosking won the 9th annual Independent Music Awards Vox Pop / Peoples Choice / Best Country Album award for "Come Sunrise".

==Soloist and with groups==
Rita is versatile, performing either as a soloist, or in duos, trios or quartets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ritahosking.com/about.html |title=Overview of Rita Hosking and her music on the Rita Hosking Homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

Rita is sometimes supported by a back-up group named Cousin Jack<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Article about Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack in ''Sacramento News & Review'' |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7oQAuE8BHG8  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/7oQAuE8BHG8 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=video of Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack performing in Berkeley, California |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}{{cbignore}}</ref> that includes:
* Sean Feder - banjo, [[dobro]], bass, percussion, vocals
* Bill Dakin - bass, guitar, vocals
* Andy Lentz - fiddle
* Kora Feder - mandolin, banjo, guitar, vocals

==Songs written by Rita Hosking==

The following singles were written by Rita Hosking and performed by others:

*Kati Penn – "I'm Going Home" on the album "My Turn to Cry" produced by [[Rob Ickes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/katipenn2 |title=Page showing Kati Penn's album "My Turn to Cry" |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

==Come Sunrise==
During the spring of 2008 at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090428021851/http://www.strawberrymusic.com/home.asp Strawberry Music Festival] Rita heard a performance of Mississippi native [[Caroline Herring]].  Hosking bought Herring's album and discovered that [http://www.richbrotherton.com/ Rich Brotherton], longtime mandolin and guitar player in [[Robert Earl Keen]]'s band, had produced it.  "I loved it," says Hosking, "so I 'My Spaced' him and said, 'Hi, my name is Rita. Would you be interested in producing my next album?' He wrote right back and said, 'Sure.'"   In addition to Brotherton, she was backed by such musicians as [[Lloyd Maines]] (father of [[Dixie Chicks]] lead singer Natalie Maines and a well-known musician and record producer), Warren Hood of the Waybacks,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waybacks.com/ |title=Homepage of the Waybacks |publisher=Waybacks.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> and Tom Van Schaik and Marty Muse from Keen's band.<ref>[https://archive.today/20130815204617/http://www.sacbee.com/music/story/1509681.html Pop Music: Rita Hosking: Down from the mountains, Davis singer-songwriter's sound mines a rich, generations-old vein, By Dixie Reid, Published: Friday, Jan. 02, 2009]</ref>

This collaboration evolved into "Come Sunrise", which was released in June 2009 and is available through CD Baby, Digstation, and iTunes.   It was recorded and produced at Ace Recording <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acerecording.net/ |title=Ace Recording homepage |publisher=Acerecording.net |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> in Austin, Texas.

As described by Stuart Mason:    "''On her new release Come Sunrise, singer-songwriter Rita Hosking reflects her upbringing in rural Shasta County. Her breed of Nor Cal country folk ain’t quite old-timey, and it ain’t quite bluegrass, but damn it’s sweet. For fans of Emmylou and Gillian, this one’s a safe bet. The songs of Rita Hoskings are as fragile as a newborn baby, and defiant as a West Virginia coal miner''."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fiddlefreak.com/2009/10/21/rita-hosking/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' on the Fiddlefreak Folk Music Blog, October 21, 2009 |publisher=Fiddlefreak.com |date=2009-10-26 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>

As described by Neil Spencer of the Guardian (UK):   "''Hosking . . . hits impressive form on this album.  Her songs are compassionate tales about ordinary folk from her north Californian background – loggers, miners, the mothers of lost sons – but there is anger as well as warmth in her voice. "Montgomery Creek Blues" and "Promise Land" in particular meld the personal and political to become state-of-the-nation songs''."<ref>{{cite news|author=Neil Spencer |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jan/03/rita-hosking-come-sunrise-review/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' in the Music Section of the Guardian (UK), January 3, 2010 |publisher=Guardian |date= 2010-01-03|accessdate=2011-11-04 |location=London}}</ref>

In July 2009 "Come Sunrise" placed Number 12 on the national Freeform American Roots Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |title=Freeform American Roots Chart of July 2009 |publisher=Tcmnradio.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126065540/http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |archive-date=2013-11-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

"Come Sunrise" was selected as one of five contenders for the country music "album of the year" of the 9th annual Independent Music Awards, announced in November 2009 (see description under ''Recognition and Awards'').

==Discography==
*''For Real'' (2018)
*''Frankie and the No-Go Road'' (2015)
*''Little Boat'' (2013)
*''Burn'' (2011) self released.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/worldfolkandjazz/8858919/Rita-Hosking-Burn-CD-review/ |title=Review of ''Burn'' in the Telegraph (UK) "Rita Hosking, a singer-songwriter from California, is on scorching form in her new CD Burn" |accessdate=2011-10-31 | location=London }}{{dead link|date=July 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
*''Come Sunrise'' (2009) self released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twangnation.com/2009/07/14/music-review-rita-hosking-come-sunrise-self-released/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' on Twang Nation |publisher=Twangnation.com |date= 14 July 2009|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p05638.htm |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' by Bob Gottlieb on ''The Folk and Acoustic Music Exchange'' |publisher=Acousticmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>
::". . . a mellow slice of Americana with deep Appalachian roots. Rita's a gifted songwriter with a strong clear voice straight from the mountains . . . . " <ref>{{cite web |last=Bogerd |first=Hal |url=http://www.hickorywind.org/002075.php |title=Hal Bogerd, review in Hickorywind |publisher=Hickorywind.org |date=2009-08-14 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006155947/http://www.hickorywind.org/002075.php |archive-date=2011-10-06 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
* ''Silver Stream'' (2007) self released.
::"Loaded with verve, spirit and out of the box energy, you don’t have to be a hardcore bluegrass fan to play this often and loud.  A top shelf recording all the way."<ref>[http://www.midwestrecord.com/2008/02/04/020408 RITA HOSKING/Silver Stream] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012145147/http://www.midwestrecord.com/2008/02/04/020408/ |date=2008-10-12 }} Volume 31/Number 96, February 4, 2008, MIDWEST RECORD, CHRIS SPECTOR, Editor and Publisher</ref>
*''Are You Ready?'' (2005) self released.<ref>{{cite web |author=Johnny J. Arguelles |url=http://www.cbaontheweb.org/reviews_read2.asp?messageID=601&curPage=1&search |title=Are You Ready? Rita Hosking, Reviewed by: B Hough |publisher=Cbaontheweb.org |date=2005-07-27 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004000120/http://www.cbaontheweb.org/reviews_read2.asp?messageID=601&curPage=1&search |archive-date=2011-10-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>[http://www.theshywriter.com/Country/Bluegrass/RITA_HOSKING_Are_You_Ready.html Review of "Are you Ready" on website "The Shy Writer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717025845/http://www.theshywriter.com/Country/Bluegrass/RITA_HOSKING_Are_You_Ready.html |date=2011-07-17 }}</ref>

In addition she has provided vocals for other recordings such as the Loose Acoustic Trio's album ''Sorrow Be Gone''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://looseacoustictrio.com |title=The Loose Acoustic Trio |publisher=The Loose Acoustic Trio |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>
